title: Converted London Art Studio Asks £1.85 Million
text:
A converted artist’s studio in West London that has been transformed into a two- bedroom home is on the market and asking for offers over £1.85 million (US$2.28 million).



From the street, the L-shaped property, which hit the market in August, looks like nothing more than a garage nestled between two larger homes, but the property occupies a very long plot and the “facade of the property belies the truly impressive proportions of the house,” listing brokerage Finlay Brewer said in a news release.



More: Former Los Angeles Dodgers Owner Sells Palm Beach Mansion for Almost $100M

It’s not clear how long the home served as a studio for, or when it was converted to a residence.



The focal point of the home is a 1,100-square-foot reception area with a double-height vaulted ceiling, exposed wooden beams and four skylights.



There are also two bedrooms, accessed by separate staircases, according to the release.



The former studio hasn’t completely forgotten its heritage—there is still an art studio within the home that could be turned into a secondary reception area or an additional bedroom, the release said. Stairs in the studio lead up to a private roof terrace.



From Penta: Why Hotels Are Getting Guests Up Close and Personal With Their Favorite Drinks

Though East London has become increasingly popular in recent years—appealing to everyone from businesses to hipsters due to its new developments, relative affordability and improving transport links—West London is holding its own.



New development projects like White City, a former industrial and broadcasting hub in the midst of a regeneration, are transforming the area into a hotbed of new housing and development.



Mansion Global could not determine who owns the home, or how much they paid for it.
